prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Taurus singles - NE group
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 6 detection of disks in singles and widely spaced multiples. These sources are the North-East grouping.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The requested flux sensitivity level is 0.1 mJy at 230 GHz, which corresponds to a 3 sigma detection limit of 0.3 mJy or M_disk = 3 x 10(-6) M(solar) using the dust opacity and spectral index from Andrews et al (2005). Band 6 is specifically chosen to facilitate comparison of the ALMA data for our proposed sample with existing millimeter data for other Taurus sources. The existing data is predominantly at 1.3 mm and taking new data at the same frequency minimizes biases introduced by comparing disk masses derived from data at different frequencies. All science goals use the continuum data only, use of the 4th module for the CO line does not decrease the overall sensitivity and provides information for later studies of the gas.

We request a correlator setup using the continuum setting for three modules with the fourth set at the frequency of CO(2-1) with a Hanning-smoothed resolution of 1.3 km/s. Models of optically thick CO line emission in Keplerian disks predict brightness temperatures of ~25 K (Dutrey, Guilloteau, & Ho, 2007) and we detected 12CO(2-1) in 14 out of the 17 targets in our Cycle 0 data. The CO brightness sensitivity level at the requested continuum sensitivity level is 0.4 K. Few of these stars have any published CO observations, including non-detections.

The goal of these observations is the detection of disks via their 1.3 mm flux rather than detailed characterization of individual disks. For these single stars and widely separated multiple systems (> 1), the requested angular resolution of 0.7 corresponds to the typical disk size and will ensure that the measured flux is concentrated in a disk. The stellar positions are all well known, thus the sidelobes resulting from these snapshot observations can be tolerated by constraining the CLEAN process to the known positions.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Taurus singles - NW group
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 6 detections of disks in singles and widely spaced multiples. These sources are the North-West grouping.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The requested flux sensitivity level is 0.1 mJy at 230 GHz, which corresponds to a 3 sigma detection limit of 0.3 mJy or M_disk = 3 x 10(-6) M(solar) using the dust opacity and spectral index from Andrews et al (2005). Band 6 is specifically chosen to facilitate comparison of the ALMA data for our proposed sample with existing millimeter data for other Taurus sources. The existing data is predominantly at 1.3 mm and taking new data at the same frequency minimizes biases introduced by comparing disk masses derived from data at different frequencies. All science goals use the continuum data only, use of the 4th module for the CO line does not decrease the overall sensitivity and provides information for later studies of the gas.

We request a correlator setup using the continuum setting for three modules with the fourth set at the frequency of CO(2-1) with a Hanning-smoothed resolution of 1.3 km/s. Models of optically thick CO line emission in Keplerian disks predict brightness temperatures of ~25 K (Dutrey, Guilloteau, & Ho, 2007) and we detected 12CO(2-1) in 14 out of the 17 targets in our Cycle 0 data. The CO brightness sensitivity level at the requested continuum sensitivity level is 0.4 K. Few of these stars have any published CO observations, including non-detections.

The goal of these observations is the detection of disks via their 1.3 mm flux rather than detailed characterization of individual disks. For these single stars and widely separated multiple systems (> 1), the requested angular resolution of 0.7 corresponds to the typical disk size and will ensure that the measured flux is concentrated in a disk. The stellar positions are all well known, thus the sidelobes resulting from these snapshot observations can be tolerated by constraining the CLEAN process to the known positions.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Taurus multiples - NE group
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 6 disk detections in closely spaced multiples with high angular resolution. These sources are the North-East grouping.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The requested flux sensitivity level is 0.1 mJy at 230 GHz, which corresponds to a 3 sigma detection limit of 0.3 mJy or M_disk = 3 x 10(-6) M(solar) using the dust opacity and spectral index from Andrews et al (2005). Band 6 is specifically chosen to facilitate comparison of the ALMA data for our proposed sample with existing millimeter data for other Taurus sources. The existing data is predominantly at 1.3 mm and taking new data at the same frequency minimizes biases introduced by comparing disk masses derived from data at different frequencies. All science goals use the continuum data only, use of the 4th module for the CO line does not decrease the overall sensitivity and provides information for later studies of the gas.

We request a correlator setup using the continuum setting for three modules with the fourth set at the frequency of CO(2-1) with a Hanning-smoothed resolution of 1.3 km/s. Models of optically thick CO line emission in Keplerian disks predict brightness temperatures of ~25 K (Dutrey, Guilloteau, & Ho, 2007) and we detected 12CO(2-1) in 14 out of the 17 targets in our Cycle 0 data. The CO brightness sensitivity level at the requested continuum sensitivity level is 0.4 K. Few of these stars have any published CO observations, including non-detections.

The goal of these observations is the detection of disks via their 1.3 mm flux rather than detailed characterization of individual disks. For these closely spaced multiple systems, the requested angular resolution of 0.18 corresponds to 25 AU at the distance to Taurus and is selected so that any disk material detected can be constrained to be either circumstellar or around 2 or more of the stellar components. The stellar positions are all well known, thus the sidelobes resulting from these snapshot observations can be tolerated by constraining the CLEAN process to the known positions.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 6 disk detections in closely spaced multiples with high angular resolution. These sources are the South-West grouping.

The goal of these observations is the detection of disks via their 1.3 mm flux rather than detailed characterization of individual disks. For these closely spaced multiple systems, the requested angular resolution of 0.18 corresponds to 25 AU at the distance to Taurus and is selected so that any disk material detected can be constrained to be either circumstellar or around 2 or more of the stellar components. The stellar positions are all well known, thus the sidelobes resulting from these snapshot observations can be tolerated by constraining the CLEAN process to the known positions.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Taurus singles - Southern group
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 6 disk detections of singles and widely spaced multiples. These sources are the Southern grouping.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The requested flux sensitivity level is 0.1 mJy at 230 GHz, which corresponds to a 3 sigma detection limit of 0.3 mJy or M_disk = 3 x 10(-6) M(solar) using the dust opacity and spectral index from Andrews et al (2005). Band 6 is specifically chosen to facilitate comparison of the ALMA data for our proposed sample with existing millimeter data for other Taurus sources. The existing data is predominantly at 1.3 mm and taking new data at the same frequency minimizes biases introduced by comparing disk masses derived from data at different frequencies. All science goals use the continuum data only, use of the 4th module for the CO line does not decrease the overall sensitivity and provides information for later studies of the gas.

We request a correlator setup using the continuum setting for three modules with the fourth set at the frequency of CO(2-1) with a Hanning-smoothed resolution of 1.3 km/s. Models of optically thick CO line emission in Keplerian disks predict brightness temperatures of ~25 K (Dutrey, Guilloteau, & Ho, 2007) and we detected 12CO(2-1) in 14 out of the 17 targets in our Cycle 0 data. The CO brightness sensitivity level at the requested continuum sensitivity level is 0.4 K. Few of these stars have any published CO observations, including non-detections.

The goal of these observations is the detection of disks via their 1.3 mm flux rather than detailed characterization of individual disks. For these single stars and widely separated multiple systems (> 1), the requested angular resolution of 0.7 corresponds to the typical disk size and will ensure that the measured flux is concentrated in a disk. The stellar positions are all well known, thus the sidelobes resulting from these snapshot observations can be tolerated by constraining the CLEAN process to the known positions.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to observe 68 single and multiple young stellar systems in Taurus to answer how protoplanetary disk mass depends on both stellar mass and multiplicity. While previous surveys show a correlation between stellar and disk mass, most sources below spectral type M3 are undetected and it is not known if the same dependence holds down to the stellar mass limit. Our Cycle 0 observations of wide binaries detected disk masses down to 10-4 MSun and revealed a range of disk mass distributions. ALMAs sensitivity and resolution enables us to observe a complete sample to tackle this issue; these observations have a sensitivity level 10 times better than previous large surveys of this region. The selected sample provides complete coverage of all stars in the disk-only phase by targeting undetected single stars and undetected or unresolved multiple systems. Using these Band 6 continuum fluxes to measure outer disk mass, combined with the wealth of ancillary data on Taurus, we will establish the influence of stellar mass and multiplicity on the potential for planet formation. This is a re-submission of a grade B, Cycle 2 proposal for which no data have yet been taken.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Infrared Processing and Analysis Center (IPAC), California Institute of Technology

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Physics & Astronomy, Swarthmore College
Division of Physics Mathematics and Astronomy, California Institute of Technology
Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory, Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics
